sen.j: 大福（だいふく）は、あずきでできた餡を餅で包んだ和菓子の一種。
sen.e: Daifuku is traditional Japanese confectionary in which Anko (sweet bean paste) is wrapped by Mochi (rice cake)..
Daifuku is a traditional Japanese confectionary consisting of mochi (rice cake) filled with anko (sweet bean paste) made from azuki beans.
Daifuku is a traditional Japanese confectionary consisting of mochi (rice cake) filled with anko (sweet bean paste) made from azuki beans.

sen.j: 大福餅（だいふくもち）とも。
sen.e: It is also called as Daifuku-mochi.
It is also known as daifuku-mochi.
It is also known as daifuku-mochi.

sen.j: 餅はきめ細かくつかれているものを使い、餡の量は餅と同量以上であることが多い。
sen.e: Well-pounded anko is used, and the amount of anko is often equal or more than that of mochi.
Smooth anko is used, and the amount of anko is often equal to or more than that of mochi.
Smooth mochi is used, and the amount of anko is often equal to or more than that of mochi.

sen.j: 食用の粉をまぶしてあることも多い。
sen.e: Daifuku is often coated with edible powder.
Daifuku are often coated with edible powder.
Daifuku are often coated with edible powder.

sen.j: 餅に豆やヨモギを加えたものや、餡の代わりにイチゴやカスタードクリームを入れたものなどさまざまなバリエーションが存在する。
sen.e: Many variations are also available such as those whose mochi contains Yomogi (wormwood) and those which are filled with strawberry or custard cream instead of anko.
There are also many variations, such as those whose mochi contains yomogi (mugwort) or beans and those which are filled with strawberry or custard cream instead of anko.
There are also many variations, such as those whose mochi contains yomogi (mugwort) or beans and those which are filled with strawberry or custard cream instead of anko.

sen.j: そのまま食べることが多いが、好みによって焼いたり、汁粉に入れたりする。
sen.e: Although Daifuku is normally taken as-is, it also can be roasted or added to sweet bean soup as desired.
Although daifuku are normally eaten as-is, they can also be roasted or added to sweet bean soup as desired.
Although daifuku are normally eaten as-is, they can also be roasted or added to sweet bean soup as desired.

sen.j: 大福を自宅で作る際は、餅に砂糖を混ぜておくと硬くなりにくい。
sen.e: When Daifuku is made at home, it is recommended to add sugar to mochi because sugar can prevent the mochi from becoming hard.
When daifuku are made at home, it is recommended to add sugar to the mochi because sugar can prevent the mochi from becoming hard.
When daifuku are made at home, it is recommended to add sugar to the mochi because sugar can prevent the mochi from becoming hard.

sen.j: しかし効かせ過ぎると、味がくどくなるので注意が必要である。
sen.e: However, be careful not to add too much sugar because it can spoil the taste of overall Daifuku.
However, be careful not to add too much sugar because it can spoil the overall taste of the daifuku.
However, be careful not to add too much sugar because it can spoil the overall taste of the daifuku.

sen.j: 工場で生産され、流通経路を介して販売される製品も同様の傾向がある。
sen.e: Commercially available Daifuku manufactured at factories also have the same tendency.
Commercially available daifuku manufactured at factories also have the same tendency.
Commercially available daifuku manufactured at factories also have the same tendency.

sen.j: 大福餅は、腹持ちがよいことから腹太餅（はらぶともち）、大腹餅（だいふくもち）と呼ばれていたという。
sen.e: It is said that Daifuku has been called as Daifuku-mochi or Harafuto-mochi and written in Chinese characters as "大腹餅" or "腹太餅" (both literally mean large belly rice cake) because feeling of fullness can last long.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Daifuku are said to have originally been called daifuku-mochi or harabuto-mochi, both written with Chinese characters meaning 'large belly rice cake', because the feeling of fullness lasts a long time.

Daifuku are said to have originally been called daifuku-mochi or harabuto-mochi, both written with Chinese characters meaning 'large belly rice cake', because the feeling of fullness lasts a long time.

sen.j: それが、吉字を使った大福餅に変化した。
sen.e: They are still called as Daifuku-mochi, but they are now written in Chinese characters as "大福餅", which has a lucky meanings (literally large happiness rice cake).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the characters were changed to mean 'large happiness rice cake', also pronounced daifuku-mochi, to bring good luck.
However, the characters were changed to mean 'large happiness rice cake', also pronounced daifuku-mochi, to bring good luck.

tit.cmt: 一部小文字に変更しました。

sen.j: - 餅にエンドウや大豆を混ぜ込んだ大福。

sen.e: Daifuku whose mochi contains Yomogi.

sen.j: ヨモギのために皮が緑がかる。
sen.e: Kusa-daifuku is green in color because of Yomogi.
The mugwort turns the mochi green

sen.j: - 皮や餡が塩味の大福。
sen.e: Daifuku whose mochi and/or anko contains salt.

sen.j: 元々は砂糖ではなく塩を味付けに使っていた。
sen.e: Originally, salt was used for flavoring instead of sugar.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Originally, salt was used for flavoring instead of sugar.
Originally, salt was used for flavoring instead of sugar.

sen.j: 現在は砂糖のともに適量の塩を加えている。
sen.e: Now, only an appropriate amount of salt is used with sugar.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Now, only a moderate amount of salt is used with sugar.
Now, only a moderate amount of salt is used with sugar.

sen.j: その他イチゴのみ、イチゴと生クリーム、イチゴと白餡などがある。
sen.e: Variations are also available such as those containing as the filler only strawberries, those containing as the filler strawberries and fresh cream, those containing as the filler strawberries and white anko, etc.
Variations include those filled with strawberries only, those filled with strawberries and fresh cream, and those filled with strawberries and white anko.
Variations include those filled with strawberries only, those filled with strawberries and fresh cream, and those filled with strawberries and white anko.

sen.j: 発祥は諸説あり、東京都新宿区住吉町 (新宿区)、群馬県前橋市、三重県津市、三重県伊賀市、滋賀県大津市、岡山県倉敷市の和菓子屋がある。
sen.e: There are several traditional Japanese confectionary stores who claims to be the inventor of Ichigo-daifuku, such as those in Sumiyoshi-cho, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo Prefecture, in Maebashi City, Gunma Prefecture, in Tsu City, Mie Prefecture, in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, in Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, etc.

Several traditional Japanese confectionary stores claim to be the inventor of Ichigo-daifuku, including ones in Sumiyoshi-cho, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo; Maebashi City, Gunma Prefecture; Tsu City, Mie Prefecture; Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture; and Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture.

Several traditional Japanese confectionary stores claim to be the inventor of Ichigo-daifuku, including ones in Sumiyoshi-cho, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo; Maebashi City, Gunma Prefecture; Tsu City, Mie Prefecture; Iga City, Mie Prefecture; Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture; and Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 三重県伊賀市 を追加しました。

sen.j: 住吉町の店は、都営地下鉄新宿線曙橋駅で下車し、フジテレビジョン『夕やけニャンニャン』の収録に参加した女子高生が口コミで広めた（当時フジテレビ新宿区河田町にあった）。
sen.e: The confectionary store in Sumiyoshi-cho became famous for Ichigo-daifuku because girl high school students who got off subway at Shinjuku-akebonobashi Station near the store to participate in recording of a television program named "Yuyake-nyannyan" conducted at a TV station (Fuji television) found the Ichigo-daifuku delicious and broadcasted it by word of mouth (Fuji television was located in Kawada-cho, Shinjuku-ku at that time).

The confectionary store in Sumiyoshi-cho became famous after word of it was spread by high school girls who got off at the nearby Akebonobashi subway station to participate in the recording of a television program named "Yuyake-nyannyan" at Fuji Television (which at the time was located in Kawada-cho, Shinjuku-ku).

The confectionary store in Sumiyoshi-cho became famous after word of it was spread by high school girls who got off at the nearby Akebonobashi subway station to participate in the recording of a television program named "Yuyake-nyannyan" at Fuji Television (which at the time was located in Kawada-cho, Shinjuku-ku).

sen.e: Other variations of fruit-containing Daifuku are also available such as those containing chestnuts, those containing the pulp of orange, those containing the pulp of peach, those containing the pulp of melon, those containing the pulp of blueberry, etc.
Other fruit daifuku include chestnut diafuku, orange daifuku, peach daifuku, melon daifuku, and blueberry daifuku.

sen.j: 徒競走に、途中で大福を食べなければならないというルールを加えた競技であり、パン食い競走の大福版といえる。

tit.j: 大福に関するキャラクター

sen.j: だいふくさん
sen.e: Daifuku-san
Daifuku-san
Daifuku-san

sen.j: 下町に三代続く和菓子の老舗『大福本舗』で毎日作られている大福餅の「だいふくさん」。
sen.e: Daifuku-san is Daifuku-mochi which is made everyday at a long-standing third-generation Japanese confectionary store named "Daifuku-honpo" located in downtown.

sen.j: 友達の「草餅くん」、「苺だいふくちゃん」、「きなこ餅くん」。

sen.j: 双子の弟でつぶ餡の「つぶだいふく」がいる。
sen.e: He has younger twin brothers named Tsubu-daifuku whose anko is Tsubu-anko.
He has a younger twin brother named Tsubu-daifuku, who is filled with tsubu-anko (anko with lager pieces of bean).
He has a younger twin brother named 'Tsubu-daifuku,' who is filled with tsubu-anko (anko with lager pieces of bean).
